Colin wrote:

>I've been working on a few non-NEAT projects lately, I'm just coming
>back round to some of this stuff now. Probably I'll be working on a few
>odds and ends for a while like the compat threshold idea, but also just
>updating the web site and thinking about which direction to go in. E.g.
>your approach of evaluating all board states got me thinking that NEAT
>in its current guise is rarely going to be able to do well at problems
>where we can only evaluate a small sub-set of test cases at each
>evaluation. The fitness functions cause the population to chase very
>specific points in the fitness space, like how kids chase a football
>around a playground, all clumped around the ball.


This is where co-evolution can come in.  When there's no specific 
fitness function, then the individuals are free to exploit any and 
every aspect of the problem.  Of course they might still get stuck in 
some tiny little area of strategy, but in theory the fact that the 
fitness function is implicit means it _can_ cover anything...


Ian
In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
